title.narrative: Public and Social Sector Transformation Project (PSST)

description.narrative: The objective of the Project is to assist the Borrower in: (i) strengthening its capacity in managing public policies and the public service; (ii) improving the efficiency of social protection spending through an integrated monitoring and targeting system; and (iii) improving the income and employability of the vulnerable population through temporary employment and training programs.

condition.narrative: Finance Agreement: Environmental Provisions (Schedule 2. Section I.D.1(a)) | Description :The Borrower, through MNSL and MALHEshall carry out Part 4 of the Project in accordance with the provisions of the Environmental Management Framework. | Frequency:CONTINUOUS

Finance Agreement: Environmental Provisions (Schedule 2. Section I.D.2) | Description :The Borrower shall cause MNSL and MALHE toenter into an agreement, on terms and conditions satisfactory to the Bank for MALHE to ensure that the Project (including TEPSub-projects) is implemented in accordance with the provisions of the Environmental Management Framework. | Frequency :CONTINUOUS

Finance Agreement: Institutional Arrangements (Schedule 2. Section I.A.1(a)) | Description :The Borrower, through MFEPA, shallmaintain, with TORs and composition satisfactory to the Bank, the Project Steering Committee, which is: (i) chaired by the MFEPAMinister and includes reps from MFEPA and its Establishment Dept and Statistics Dept, Cabinet Secretariat, MHST, MNSL and MoE; and(ii) responsible, inter alia, for providing strategic direction and oversight of Project implementation. | Frequency :CONTINUOUS

Finance Agreement: Institutional Arrangements (Schedule 2. Section I.A.1(b)) | Description :The Borrower, through MFEPA, shallmaintain, with TORs and composition satisfactory to the Bank, the PMU: (i) established within the MFEPA and staffed with a coreteam of a project coordinator, 3 specialists (FM, procurement & communication); & (ii) responsible for overall coordination ofProject implementation and for providing tech support to the implementing agencies for Project implementation. | Frequency:CONTINUOUS

Finance Agreement: Institutional Arrangements (Schedule 2. Section I.A.2(a)) | Description :The Borrower shall carry out theProject in a timely manner and in accordance with provisions of the Operational Manual, acceptable to the Bank. | Frequency:CONTINUOUS

title.narrative: Number of databases of SP Programs transferred to the Single Beneficiary Registry
Number of public servants in line ministries capable to develop policy proposals in line with new standards.
The Training Program (TP) beneficiaries placement rate is at least 40% higher than the one for non-enrolled eligible beneficiariesthree months after the end of the internship phase.
Number of Memorandums of Understanding signed with the implementing agencies of SP program
Percentage of beneficiaries of the TP who graduate from the program
Percentage of TEP subprojects that satisfactorily completed their proposed targets
Percentage of beneficiaries of the TEP subprojects who complete the subproject
% of career public servants covered by the new Public Service Act establishing a single employment regime
Non-established public servants integrated under a common regime by Cabinet

baseline.value: 55% of public servants are not governed by the civil service law.

target.value: 100% of non-established posts are eliminated. The public service database lists all public employees with appropriate legalstatus, defined in law.

actual.value: 55% of public servants are not governed by the civil service law.

title.narrative: New decentralized personnel management system established.

baseline.value: Centralized HR management in the established civil service and fully decentralized, partially regulated HR management fornon-established employees.

target.value: HRM network institutionalized; Central Civil Service Authority monitors civil service compliance;

actual.value: Centralized HR management in the established civil service and fully decentralized, partially regulated HR management fornon-established employees.

title.narrative: Staffing levels are aligned with core tasks

baseline.value: Employment records exist for approximately 85% of public employees of which 55% non-established.

target.value: All ministries and government agencies completed staff lists.

actual.value: Employment records exist for approximately 85% of public employees of which 55% non-established.

title.narrative: Legal Framework for Policy Making and Coordination established

baseline.value: Policy development and coordination process is ad hoc

target.value: Policy approval process, including prior review, is institutionalized.

actual.value: Policy development and coordination process is ad hoc

title.narrative: % of ministries and depts that have the capacity to manage their HR w/in the delegated authority to hire, admin. professional develop. and disciplinary action, and manage perform. and apply incentives

baseline.value: Public Service Commission has centralized authority over hiring, firing and disciplinary actions.

target.value: 80% of ministries and departments manage HR within the delegated authority. Continued in 'comment' section.

actual.value: Public Service Commission has centralized authority over hiring, firing and disciplinary actions.

title.narrative: % of beneficiaries in the Single Registry of Beneficiaries identified with the NBMIS as non-eligible.
% of poor Antiguans identified by National Beneficiaries Management Information System (NBMIS) and enrolled in a social protection program.
% of policies approved by the Cabinet aligned with the medium-term Government priorities and reflected in the Government's Medium-Term Strategic Development Plan (MTSDP)
The Temporary Employment Program (TEP) beneficiaries labor income is at least 40% higher than the one for non enrolled eligible beneficiaries over the six month period of program implementation.
Beneficiaries of Labor Market programs - Female (number)
